ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual lecture, cameras on :), lots of back and forth
n/a
Live virtual seminar and office hours.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Reviewed and learned a variety of grammatical concepts, practiced listening and speaking skills, learned about and read a variety of French literature.
I improved in French grammar, vocab, and sytax, and conjugations
I learned French grammar and vocabulary. I practiced writing, listening, and speaking skills.

My French reading and listening skills have improved significantly by reading novels and watching films in French. I've also learnt grammars more systematically and practiced speaking in class discussions.

I learned the French language skills that are applicable for an intermediate/advanced level language learner while also developing an appreciation for French literature and film in the process. This course solidifies every aspect of your French, namely grammar, speaking, reading, writing and especially listening.
French grammar, speaking, and reading comprehension

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course had a lot of work, and while much of it was repetitive, it was overall effective in drilling the material and helping with memorization. The workload quickly became manageable, and I found that my French improved significantly.

The audio activities we had assigned every night were a lot, and they were also kind of difficult to learn the material when these audio activities were the ones introducing you to a new concept for the first time. I would have liked activities that would have served more as a practice to reaffirm topics, rather than teaching us. Teaching us was best left to in-class time.

Strengths: very well organized series of audio recordings and corresponding exercises; class atmosphere that was conducive to participation and learning; Weaknesses: not a lot of opportunities to practice long speaking responses
I've fully enjoyed the course and all the assigned readings and films. I think the professor is especially good at encouraging meaningful discussions.

This course was taught very well, and I think that all of the concepts taught in this course were very appropriate for this level. Having audio programs everyday improves your listening comprehension skills immensely, and the listening programs align nicely with the exam material. The great thing about this course is how fair it is; if you put in the effort, improvement is guaranteed.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Zoom class was far more effective and enjoyable than I expected, and I don't think the learning experience was significantly diminished.
The teachers did a great job at engaging us virtually
The Zoom format facilitated learning by discussion.
I think the format of the course works quite well in an online learning environment. Students are able to join discussions readily during meetings with the entire class as well as in breakout rooms.

I thought this course adapted well onto the online format. Only thing I would have preferred is more options for office hours. I wish I could have gone to office hours more often but I usually had a class at the same time, so more times for office hours would be great!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes- the class was enjoyable and I learned a lot.
It's not an easy class, but take it if you like French and want to get better.
I would recommend this course to any student who wants to improve their French proficiency.
I would love to recommend this course to others, because all the units in this course are super interesting and you get to build a community throughout the semester!

Yes I would. If you want to improve your French and cultivate an appreciation for French literature/film, this class is a great place to start! Even though having class and assignments everyday may seem intimidating, this class is set up for you to succeed, and with time you will adjust to the rhythm.

This class is worth the effort that it demands. I hadn't taken French in quite a few years and was worried about not only how I would find reacclimatizing to the language but also how well I would pick it back up, but the fast pace and consistent, structured work load enabled me to hit the ground running. The professors were personable, understanding and very willing to help and make themselves available. I recommend this class, just make sure you can dedicate yourself to it.

Yes I would definitely recommend this course if you enjoy French. Mme DeVos really cares about each student and wants everyone to be engaged. However, there is a lot of work so if you dont like French then I would say this class isnt for you.
